comments:
The Java debug refactoring tests are starting to have intermittent failures. The refactoring phase of the test completes/passes but then our cleanup sometimes fails with exceptions like the following. The failures are sporadic and can be different tests from run to run, but the failure is always the same root problem.

To reproudce:

* In a new workspace, check out the following projects:
   - org.eclipse.jdt.debug.tests
   - org.eclipse.test.performance
   - org.eclipse.test.performance.win32

* apply attached patch (reduces debug test suite to refactoring tests)
* Run the test suite as a JUnit Plug-in Test
   - Project: org.eclipse.jdt.debug.tests
   - Test class: org.eclipse.jdt.debug.tests.AutomatedSuite

Created an attachment (id=30621)
patch to reduce test suite to refactoring tests

I have tracked down the cause of the failure, but I don't have an explanation for why it only started failing recently.  For reference, here is how I debug this kind of failure:

1) Set a breakpoint at the point of failure
2) Configure the breakpoint to suspend the entire VM
3) Run until failure occurs.
4) See what other threads are doing at the time of failure.

Sure enough, in this case the "Java indexing" thread had an open file input stream on the file that could not be deleted.  Here is the stack trace of the indexer at the point of failure:

Thread [Java indexing] (Suspended)
	WinNTFileSystem.getLength(File) line: not available [native method]
	File.length() line: 816
	Util.getFileCharContent(File, String) line: 70
	JavaSearchDocument.getCharContents() line: 53
	SourceIndexer.indexDocument() line: 73
	JavaSearchParticipant.indexDocument(SearchDocument, IPath) line: 72
	IndexManager.indexDocument(SearchDocument, SearchParticipant, Index, IPath) line: 297
	IndexManager$1.execute(IProgressMonitor) line: 608
	IndexManager(JobManager).run() line: 372
	Thread.run() line: 816

If you look at Util.getFileCharCount, you can see that on the previous line it opened an input stream on the file.  In windows, a file cannot be deleted when a thread or process has an open input stream on that file.

CCing Philippe: has anything changed in the indexer code recently?

My suggestion is for the Java indexer to obtain a scheduling rule on the file that is being read, thus blocking other threads that are trying to manipulate the file.
Since this is an interaction between JDT core and JDT debug test suites, it will need to be resolved by one of those two.

I don't think we changed the indexer in recent past. Now with EFS and new debug framework, could things have changed so that timing becomes an issue ?
The background indexer is always potentially colliding with resource deletion, especially when running tests which are programmatically causing many resource changes in a fraction of second. In normal user scenario, we haven't seen major issues.

Jerome, can you indicate how to protect test suites from background indexing ? I am thinking of exposing our magic #waitUntilIndexesReady()
Note: recent changes in the "flexible debug platform" will not be a factor in these tests. The tests are purely headless refactoring tests and do not involve debug sessions/views (just breakpoints).

(In reply to comment #3)
> My suggestion is for the Java indexer to obtain a scheduling rule on the file
> that is being read, thus blocking other threads that are trying to manipulate
> the file.
This is asking for deadlocks since Java search operations are usually waiting for the indexing to finish. If a search operation takes a scheduling rule that contains the file being indexed, then we would deadlock.
Fixed debug test suite to wait for indicies to be ready before deleting resources. Introduced abstract refactoring test with "wait for indexes" method provided by Jerome.

Sudhan, you should file your bug against JDT core. This bug dealt with a problem in the java debug test suite, but com.appperfect.devtest.util.JavaModelUtilities is not using code in the java debugger.
